resources.string: Generalized Anxiety Disorder is different than having a phobia about something in the sense that people with GAD have an uneasy feeling about life in general. \nOften associated with feelings of dread or unease, you are in a state of constant worry over everything. There is no “off” switch. \nIf you are suffering from Generalized Anxiety Disorder, you are experiencing a constant state of worry – and you cannot avoid it, because life, in general, is causing you anxiety.

• Perpetual state of constant worry
• Inability to relax or enjoy quiet time
• Muscle tightness or body aches
• Feeling tense
• Avoidance of stressful situations
• Difficulty concentrating or focusing on things
• No tolerance for uncertainty – needing to know what is going to happen and how it is going to happen
• Constant feelings of dread or apprehension
• Feeling overwhelmed and avoiding things or situations because of it
• Intrusive thoughts of things that cause you to worry – even when you try to stop thinking about them
• Feeling like you can’t control your emotions and constant worry – nothing you do helps you to relax
• Not being able to sleep at all or to sleep well because you are in a constant state of worry
• Feeling jumpy, on edge, or restless
• Stomach upset – including nausea and diarrhea
• Fatiguing easily
• Heart palpitations – feeling like your heart is racing
• Trembles or shakes
• Sweating and dry mouth
• Having difficulty breathing and/or feeling like you are choking
• Feeling lightheaded or dizzy
• Cold chills or hot flashes
• Numbness or tingling sensations
• Feeling like you have a lump in your throat
• Persistent irritability

Studies have shown that if you are living with Generalized Anxiety Disorder, you are more likely to also suffer from other mental health issues and ailments. \nCommon conditions that are associated with Generalized Anxiety Disorder include depression(https://www.psycom.net/depression.central.html), irritable bowel syndrome, stress, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder(https://www.psycom.net/adult-adhd/), and substance abuse(https://www.psycom.net/depression.central.substance.html).

Depression is more than just feeling sad. Everyone feels upset or unmotivated from time to time, but depression is more serious. \nIt is a mood disorder characterized by prolonged feelings of sadness and loss of interest in daily activities. If these symptoms persist for a period of at least two weeks, it is considered a depressive episode.

3. Brainstorm possible solutions. Be creative and come up with as many solutions as you can think of. Some ideas may be way out there, but don’t worry about evaluating them yet. If you want to solve a conflict you’re having with your parents by escaping on a rainbow unicorn, write it down! Keep an open mind and list anything that comes to mind, plausible or not.

2. Set some goals. Focus on the steps you can take to resolve things, rather than just thinking about what you’d like to happen. Maybe you wish you had more money. Make a list of all the ways you can save or earn more. It could mean walking to school rather than taking the bus, or applying for a part-time job.
7. Put your solutions into practice. Have faith in yourself and make the commitment to try out one of your solutions.

5. Examine the consequences. Go through the options you’ve got left, and for each one write a list of their pros and cons.

4. Rule out any obvious poor options. Okay, reality check. Evaluate your list of ideas and rule out the ones that are unrealistic or unhelpful. Bye-bye, rainbow unicorn. But how about trying to see things from your parents’ point of view? That option should probably stay on your list.
8. How did it go? So, you tried it out. What happened? If you had more than one solution and the first didn’t work, move on to another one.

They use phrases like \"I\'m feeling suicidal, I\'m scared\", \"I need to talk/need help\", \"I don\'t know how I can keep going\", \"I feel hopeless\"

• Finding a therapist or a support group: Speaking to someone can make you feel better and improve your mental health.

• Building a support network: You don't have to deal with the crisis alone. People that you choose to confide in can help you. You can reach out via social networks, to your local community or to a close group of friends/family.

• Use your support network: Express yourself to people you trust. Keep an open mind to the advice that others give, understand that its coming from a good place. Show appreciation for the people who are helping you get through these tough times.

A safety plan is designed to guide you through a crisis. 
1. Recognize your personal warning signs: What thoughts, images, moods, situations, and behaviors indicate to you that a crisis may be developing? Write these down in your own words.
2. Use your own coping strategies: List things that you can do on your own to help you not act on urges to harm yourself.
3. Socialize with others who may offer support and distraction from the crisis: List people and social settings that may help take your mind off of difficult thoughts or feelings.
4. Contact family members or friends who may help to resolve a crisis: Make a list of people who are supportive and who you feel you can talk to when under stress.
5. Contact mental health professionals or agencies: Make a list of names, numbers and/or locations of clinicians, local emergency rooms, and crisis hotlines. 
6. Ensure your environment is safe: Have you thought of ways in which you might harm yourself? Work with a counselor to develop a plan to limit your access to these means.
If you think a person may be at imminent risk, call a suicide helpline or local emergency services.
